legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is a prescription medication available via statewide standing order. State law allows pharmacists to dispense without a patient-specific prescription. OTC naloxone is now also available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: The Alabama State Health Officer issued a statewide standing order on March 8, 2018 (effective immediately). This standing order authorizes licensed pharmacists to dispense naloxone to individuals at risk of opioid overdose or to family members, friends, or others in a position to assist. The standing order automatically expires if/when naloxone becomes fully OTC. Recipients must complete a form attesting to overdose risk and training received.
key_statutes_or_policies: Alabama State Health Officer Standing Order (March 8, 2018)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects persons who call 911 in good faith for someone experiencing an overdose from misdemeanor drug possession charges, provided they use their real name, remain at scene, and reasonably believe they were first to call.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Does not protect the overdose victim themselves. Must meet all three conditions (good faith, real name, remain at scene) for immunity.

pharmacies.mechanism: Licensed pharmacists can dispense naloxone directly under the statewide standing order without a prescription. Pharmacists must provide basic overdose recognition and naloxone administration training. OTC naloxone (Narcan nasal spray) is also available at retail pharmacies.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan typically $45-65 per 2-pack at chain pharmacies; generic naloxone $23-66 with GoodRx coupons. Medicaid covers with varying copayments (typically $0-3). Uninsured/underinsured individuals can access free naloxone through community programs.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Alabama Medicaid covers naloxone with no copayment. Coverage applies to both generic and brand-name formulations.

community_programs.name: Jefferson County Department of Health (JCDH) Naloxone Program
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits (nasal spray and intramuscular), fentanyl test strips, overdose training, harm reduction supplies
community_programs.eligibility: Open to anyone; priority for individuals at risk of opioid overdose and close contacts. Free naloxone offered via partnership with Alabama Department of Mental Health.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Jefferson County (Birmingham area); also provides naloxone through vending machines converted from newspaper stands

community_programs.name: Alabama Department of Mental Health (ADMH)
community_programs.services: Coordinates naloxone distribution to counties; funds peer providers for community naloxone distribution; fentanyl test strips
community_programs.eligibility: Statewide through county partners; available to individuals at risk and community members
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through county health departments

community_programs.name: Addiction Prevention Coalition (APC)
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, harm reduction services, community outreach
community_programs.eligibility: Central Alabama residents; focus on populations at risk
community_programs.in_person_locations: Central Alabama

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for individuals who use drugs or are closely connected to those who do; priority given to those with limited access through pharmacies/insurance
mail_based_programs.notes: Naloxone mailed directly to address. Requires completion of brief online form. Program operates via partnerships with 30+ harm reduction organizations nationwide.

mail_based_programs.name: Alabama State Naloxone Mailing Program
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Alabama residents who complete brief online naloxone training
mail_based_programs.notes: State mails free naloxone and fentanyl test strips to trained individuals. Training available online at state health department website.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Fastest option: Visit any Alabama pharmacy and ask for naloxone OTC (Narcan nasal spray, ~$45-65) or ask pharmacist about standing order dispensing (often free/low-cost). For free immediate access: Contact Jefferson County Department of Health in Birmingham area or call Alabama Department of Mental Health for county referrals. For mail delivery within 1-2 weeks: Contact NEXT Distro (nextdistro.org) or complete Alabama state training for free mailing program.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas may have limited pharmacy access; call county health departments for delivery options. Cost barriers: OTC Narcan is $45-65; generic naloxone $23-66 with GoodRx. Medicaid covers with $0-3 copay. Uninsured/underinsured: free naloxone available through county health departments and NEXT Distro. Stigma/privacy concerns: mail-based programs (NEXT Distro, state program) offer discreet delivery; online training eliminates face-to-face interaction.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Limited information available. Contact JCDH or ADMH for language-accessible materials. State naloxone training and forms available in English; accessibility accommodations may be available upon request.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is available via statewide standing order and pharmacist prescribing authority. Pharmacists can independently prescribe after completion of approved training. OTC naloxone also available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: The Chief Medical Officer of the Alaska Department of Health and Social Services issued a statewide standing order (September 30, 2019, renewed indefinitely via 2021 amendment). The standing order does NOT authorize pharmacy dispensing directly, but rather authorizes approved Project HOPE Overdose Response Programs (ORPs) to distribute naloxone to anyone at risk of opioid overdose or in a position to assist. Training requirements vary by program.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects persons who seek medical/law enforcement assistance for themselves or others experiencing overdose from prosecution for possession, use, or display of controlled substances, provided evidence was discovered due to seeking help and caller remained at scene.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Requires caller to reasonably believe overdose was occurring, remain at scene, cooperate with emergency personnel, and provide identification. Protects both caller and overdosed person.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists can independently prescribe and dispense naloxone after completing an approved opioid overdose drug training program. No standing order required from another prescriber. OTC naloxone also available at pharmacies.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan typically $45-65 per 2-pack; generic naloxone $23-66 with GoodRx coupons. Some community health centers and ORP programs offer free naloxone.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Alaska Medicaid covers naloxone; specific copayment/coverage details require verification with individual plans.

community_programs.name: Project HOPE (Alaska Department of Health and Social Services)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits (Narcan 4mg nasal spray, 2 doses per kit with gloves, instruction brochure, carrying case), overdose education, training resources
community_programs.eligibility: Open to anyone at risk of opioid overdose or in a position to assist. Approved Overdose Response Programs (ORPs) distribute kits.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through approved ORPs and community partners; Project HOPE has multiple partner organizations throughout Alaska

community_programs.name: Local Overdose Response Programs (ORPs)
community_programs.type: community organizations, drug treatment programs, harm reduction organizations
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, overdose training, harm reduction supplies
community_programs.eligibility: Individuals at risk of opioid overdose; varies by specific organization
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide; contact Project HOPE for local ORP finder

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for individuals who use drugs or closely connected to those who do
mail_based_programs.notes: Naloxone mailed directly. Serves as backup/alternative access point for those unable to access Project HOPE programs.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Fastest option: Visit any Alaska pharmacy and ask for OTC Narcan ($45-65) or ask if pharmacist is trained to prescribe/dispense naloxone (often free/low-cost). For free naloxone: Contact Project HOPE or visit Project HOPE partner organization website for nearest approved Overdose Response Program. For rural areas with limited pharmacy access, Project HOPE programs often provide free kits.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Alaska's vast rural areas present significant challenges. Many remote villages lack pharmacies; Project HOPE aims to address this through community programs and mail-based options. Cost: OTC Narcan $45-65; free through Project HOPE ORPs. Pharmacist training requirements may limit some pharmacy access in smaller towns. Workaround: use NEXT Distro for mail delivery or identify nearest ORP.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Limited information on language accessibility. Alaska has large populations of Alaska Native languages; contact Project HOPE directly for culturally and linguistically appropriate resources.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is widely available via statewide standing order allowing any licensed pharmacist to dispense without prescription. Co-prescription required in certain opioid prescribing scenarios. OTC naloxone also available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: The Chief Medical Officer of Arizona Department of Health Services issued a statewide standing order (effective August 20, 2021, renewable annually). This standing order authorizes ANY Arizona-licensed pharmacist to dispense naloxone to any person without a prescription. Pharmacists must follow board-approved protocols and document dispensing. No training requirement specified for patients receiving naloxone.
key_statutes_or_policies: Arizona State Health Officer Standing Order (August 20, 2021)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects persons who call 911 in good faith for themselves or another person experiencing a drug-related overdose from prosecution for possession or use of controlled substances and drug paraphernalia, if evidence discovered due to calling for help.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Both caller and overdosed person receive protection. Calling may be considered mitigating factor in other drug prosecutions.

pharmacies.mechanism: Any Arizona-licensed pharmacist can dispense naloxone directly under statewide standing order without a prescription. Available at chain pharmacies (Walgreens, CVS, etc.) and independent pharmacies. OTC naloxone (Narcan) widely stocked.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan typically $45-65 per 2-pack at chain pharmacies; generic naloxone $23-66 with GoodRx coupons. Many pharmacies dispense free under standing order. Arizona Health Care Cost Containment System (AHCCCS/Medicaid) distributes free naloxone kits.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: AHCCCS (Arizona Medicaid) covers naloxone with no copayment. AHCCCS distributes naloxone kits to enrollees at no cost as part of overdose prevention efforts.

community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits, fentanyl test strips, overdose prevention training, distribution to law enforcement, community health departments, healthcare facilities, schools
community_programs.eligibility: Organizations can apply; individuals access through community organizations or pharmacies
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide; distributed through community partners, law enforcement, fire departments

community_programs.eligibility: Pima County residents; at-risk populations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Pima County (Tucson area)

community_programs.services: Naloxone training, distribution, community education on overdose prevention
community_programs.eligibility: Community members; focus on at-risk populations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple coalitions throughout Arizona

community_programs.services: Naloxone access advocacy, first responder training, community naloxone distribution, partnerships with health departments
community_programs.eligibility: All Arizona residents
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide with focus on underserved communities

mail_based_programs.eligibility: Individuals who use drugs or closely connected to those who do
mail_based_programs.notes: Backup access option for those unable to access pharmacy or community programs

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Fastest option: Walk into any Arizona pharmacy and ask for OTC Narcan ($45-65) or standing order naloxone (often free). No prescription or ID required. Most chain pharmacies (Walgreens, CVS, Fry's pharmacies) stock naloxone readily available same-day. For free naloxone: Contact ADHS, local community health department, or one of the community coalitions. AHCCCS members: ask at pharmacy about free AHCCCS-provided kits.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Cost barrier for uninsured: OTC Narcan $45-65; generic $23-66 with GoodRx; standing order at pharmacies often free. Stigma/privacy: Use mail-based NEXT Distro for discreet delivery. Rural access: Some remote areas may have limited pharmacies; contact ADHS or local health department for mobile/outreach programs.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Arizona has large Spanish-speaking population. Some community coalitions and health departments provide Spanish-language naloxone training and materials. Contact specific organizations for language availability. Audio/visual training resources available through ADHS website.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is available via statewide protocol allowing pharmacists to dispense without a patient-specific prescription. Healthcare providers can prescribe via standing order or individual authorization. OTC naloxone also available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Arkansas issued a statewide Naloxone Protocol allowing Arkansas-licensed pharmacists to initiate naloxone therapy (ordering, dispensing, administering). Pharmacists can dispense to anyone at increased risk of opioid overdose or family members, friends, or others in a position to assist. Protocol was issued under Arkansas Code § 17-92-101(18) and approved by Arkansas State Medical Board and State Board of Pharmacy.
key_statutes_or_policies: Arkansas Naloxone Protocol (State Medical Board and Board of Pharmacy approved)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects persons who call 911 in good faith for drug overdose (themselves or others) from prosecution for possession of controlled substances, if evidence discovered due to calling for help. Also protects from parole/probation violations for drug possession discovered via overdose call.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Caller must act in good faith. No protections for distribution/trafficking. Person who overdosed only protected if they called for help themselves.

pharmacies.mechanism: Arkansas-licensed pharmacists can dispense naloxone directly under statewide protocol without a prescription. Pharmacists assess eligibility (at-risk status) and provide naloxone. No prescription needed from another provider. OTC naloxone also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan typically $45-65 per 2-pack; generic naloxone $23-66 with GoodRx coupons. Protocol-dispensed naloxone often free or low-cost through pharmacies. Arkansas Medicaid covers naloxone.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Arkansas Medicaid covers naloxone with varying copayments. Most pharmacies dispense protocol-authorized naloxone at no cost to Medicaid members.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is widely available through multiple mechanisms: pharmacist furnishing under statewide protocol, standing orders via community organizations, and prescriber authorization. OTC naloxone also available. California has among the most expansive naloxone access laws.

standing_order_or_protocol.type: statewide standing order and pharmacist furnishing protocol
standing_order_or_protocol.description: California allows both standing orders and pharmacist furnishing protocols. Pharmacists can furnish naloxone to persons with opioid use history or close contacts of people with opioid use history under standardized procedures and protocols (Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 4052.01). Community organizations can receive standing orders from the state. Pharmacists must complete 1-hour naloxone-specific training and provide consultation before dispensing.
key_statutes_or_policies: California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) Naloxone Distribution Project

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects persons who call 911 in good faith for drug or alcohol overdose (themselves or others) from prosecution for possession or use of controlled substances or drug paraphernalia, if they don't interfere with emergency personnel. Applies to both caller and person who overdosed.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: One of the broadest GSL protections in the nation. Protects both caller and overdosed person. Does not apply if person interferes with emergency personnel.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists can furnish naloxone directly under statewide protocol to anyone with opioid use history or close contacts of people with opioid use history, without a prescription. Pharmacist must complete 1-hour training and provide consultation. OTC Narcan widely available at chain pharmacies.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan typically $45-65 per 2-pack at chain pharmacies; generic naloxone $23-66 with GoodRx coupons. Many pharmacies furnish standing-order naloxone free or low-cost. California Medicaid (Medi-Cal) covers naloxone.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: California Medi-Cal covers naloxone with no copayment. Coverage applies to generic and brand-name formulations dispensed by pharmacists.

community_programs.services: Free naloxone (generic 4mg or Narcan brand 4mg nasal spray) distributed to eligible organizations; entities receive shipments directly to their addresses
community_programs.eligibility: Fire, EMS, first responders; schools/universities; tribal entities; county public health/behavioral health departments; law enforcement; community organizations including harm reduction orgs and opioid coalitions
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide; organizations apply and receive shipments; distributed through community partner networks

community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, public education, harm reduction services
community_programs.eligibility: Santa Barbara County residents

mail_based_programs.eligibility: Individuals who use drugs or closely connected to those who do
mail_based_programs.notes: Provides free naloxone via mail; operates with partnerships to 30+ programs nationwide; priority for those with limited access

mail_based_programs.provider_type: state program distributed through community organizations
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Eligible organizations apply for distributions
mail_based_programs.cost: Free for eligible organizations and individuals served
mail_based_programs.notes: Organizations can apply to receive naloxone shipments for distribution to community members

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Fastest option: Walk into any California pharmacy and ask for OTC Narcan ($45-65) or ask if pharmacist can furnish naloxone under protocol (often free with Medi-Cal; low-cost otherwise). No prescription or eligibility verification required. For free naloxone: Contact local county health department, community opioid coalition, or harm reduction organization. Organizations can apply to DHCS Naloxone Distribution Project for bulk shipments. For mail delivery: Use NEXT Distro (free, 1-2 weeks).
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Cost: OTC Narcan $45-65; generic $23-66 with GoodRx; Medi-Cal covers $0; uninsured/underinsured can access free through community programs and NDP. Rural/remote areas: County health departments; mail-based options (NEXT Distro, NDP). Stigma/privacy: Use mail-based programs or speak to pharmacist confidentially.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: California has very diverse population. Many county health departments and community organizations provide Spanish and other language-accessible naloxone training and materials. DHCS provides resources; contact specific county or organization for language availability. Some organizations provide video/audio training for accessibility.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Colorado law (C.R.S. §12-36-117.7) authorizes licensed prescribers to issue standing orders for naloxone dispensing. The Chief Medical Officer of CDPHE may issue standing orders for eligible entities. Authorized providers can distribute naloxone to individuals at risk of overdose, first responders, and harm reduction organizations without individual patient prescriptions.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects anyone acting in good faith who administers naloxone to someone experiencing an opioid overdose from civil and criminal liability; expanded in 2020 to include expired naloxone
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Protection applies regardless of whether naloxone was expired at time of use if obtained via valid prescription or standing order

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacies can dispense naloxone under statewide standing orders issued by medical professionals with prescriptive authority. Pharmacists may dispense to anyone without a patient-specific prescription under approved standing orders.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (2-dose nasal spray) approximately $45 at retail; generic naloxone prescription options available for less; free options through community programs
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Naloxone covered by Colorado Medicaid with no copayment

community_programs.services: Free naloxone distribution, overdose education, harm reduction supplies including syringe services
community_programs.eligibility: Denver residents; open to anyone at risk of overdose or in position to assist
community_programs.in_person_locations: Denver; mail distribution available for Denver residents via online form

community_programs.type: harm reduction org, syringe services provider
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, syringe services, overdose prevention education, drug checking supplies
community_programs.eligibility: Open to people who use drugs and community members
community_programs.in_person_locations: Denver (936 E. 18th Avenue), Pueblo, Colorado Springs, Fort Collins, Grand Junction, Greeley

community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, overdose prevention training, harm reduction services

mail_based_programs.notes: Operated through NEXT Distro partnership with Harm Reduction Action Center (HRAC) serving Colorado. Requires completion of online training module. Free naloxone with fentanyl test strips and education materials.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Walk into any Colorado pharmacy and ask for naloxone without a prescription (available under standing order); visit a harm reduction program like Colorado Health Network's Access Point or DDPHE in Denver for free naloxone and training; call DDPHE or local harm reduction organizations; order free naloxone by mail through NEXT Distro at nextdistro.org.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas may have limited in-person access—use mail-based NEXT Distro or contact regional programs (Points West in Jeffco, Arapahoe County, Broomfield, Larimer/Weld, Boulder programs). Stigma in pharmacies can be addressed by knowing naloxone is legally available without prescription. Cost barrier overcome through free community distribution and state programs. Transportation barriers addressed by mail delivery options.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: No specific language accommodation information located; DDPHE and harm reduction organizations provide training and materials in multiple formats; online resources available through state health department

standing_order_or_protocol.type: statewide pharmacist prescribing protocol and local standing orders
standing_order_or_protocol.description: Connecticut Public Act 15-198 authorizes pharmacists who complete training and certification to prescribe and dispense naloxone to any person requesting it. Public Act 18-166 allows prescribing practitioners and pharmacists to enter agreements with law enforcement, EMS, and community health organizations to distribute naloxone. Agreements require training of distribution personnel.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects anyone administering naloxone to a person experiencing opioid overdose from civil liability and criminal prosecution; person experiencing overdose also protected
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Public Act 11-210 (enacted 2011) provides comprehensive protection; no requirement to remain on scene specified in statute

pharmacies.mechanism: Connecticut pharmacists certified to prescribe naloxone can dispense directly to customers requesting it without a physician prescription. Department of Consumer Protection maintains list of certified pharmacists. Patients must see pharmacist in person to receive prescription and medication.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan $45 at retail; prescription naloxone through certified pharmacists free or low cost; covered by CT Medicaid and commercial insurance
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Naloxone covered by CT Medicaid (HUSKY and CADAP) with select naloxone products; Narcan 4mg nasal spray is preferred; auxiliary products not covered

community_programs.services: Naloxone and overdose response education, syringe exchange, HIV testing, harm reduction counseling, drug treatment referrals, safer sex kits
community_programs.eligibility: People who inject drugs; open to community
community_programs.in_person_locations: Mobile van in Hartford South End at Park Street & Hungerford Street; operates Monday (or Tuesday if holiday), Thursday, Friday 8-10am and 1:15-2:45pm

community_programs.name: Connecticut substance abuse treatment and prevention programs
community_programs.services: Naloxone prescription, training, and distribution through affiliated providers
community_programs.eligibility: Individuals enrolled in treatment or seeking services
community_programs.in_person_locations: Throughout state via substance abuse treatment agencies and community health centers

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro (National Program - Serves Connecticut)
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, family members, first responders unable to access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.notes: Connecticut residents can access free naloxone by mail through national NEXT Distro program. Includes overdose education and fentanyl test strips. Requires reliable mailing address and internet access.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any participating Connecticut pharmacy with a pharmacist certified to prescribe naloxone—use Department of Consumer Protection naloxone map to find nearest location; speak with your doctor or substance abuse treatment provider; contact local health department or ACT Programs in Hartford; order by mail through NEXT Distro.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural pharmacy access may be limited—use DCP map to locate certified pharmacists or mail-based NEXT Distro; stigma in some pharmacies can be addressed by knowing pharmacists are trained to provide naloxone without judgment; cost addressed through Medicaid coverage and free community programs.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Department of Consumer Protection maintains educational resources; ACT Programs provide harm reduction counseling in accessible formats; no specific multilingual naloxone training information located

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Legal and widely accessible through standing orders, pharmacies, and community-based programs

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Delaware authorizes standing orders for naloxone under Title 16 §3001G. DHSS creates statewide standing orders for public safety personnel and community-based naloxone access. Community-based agencies and pharmacies can dispense intranasal naloxone (Narcan spray and generic) and auto-injector naloxone under approved standing orders. Training is required prior to dispensing.
key_statutes_or_policies: Delaware Code Title 16 §3001G (Administration of Naloxone by Public Safety and Community-Based Programs)
DHSS Community-Based Naloxone Access Program Standing Order (effective July 2025)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects public safety personnel and laypersons acting in good faith who administer naloxone from civil liability and professional licensing sanctions; protects prescribers issuing standing orders
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Delaware law does not specify requirement to remain on scene; healthcare providers who prescribe under standing order also protected

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacies dispense naloxone under Delaware statewide standing orders without individual prescriptions. Pharmacists dispense to anyone and to persons designated by the standing order. Recent standing order (July 2025) authorizes approved community-based agencies and participating pharmacies to distribute kits.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $45 at retail pharmacies; free naloxone through state and community programs; generic options lower cost
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Naloxone covered by Delaware Medicaid with no copayment; state programs provide free naloxone to eligible residents

community_programs.name: Delaware Division of Public Health - Free Naloxone Mail Program
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits mailed to Delaware residents without prescription; includes overdose education and administration instructions
community_programs.eligibility: Any Delaware resident; free mail distribution requires no application barriers
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide distribution through state health department

community_programs.name: Community Collaboration of Delaware - SAVE Program
community_programs.services: Naloxone training and distribution program, completely free; overdose prevention education
community_programs.eligibility: Community members; those at risk or likely to witness overdose
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through Community Collaboration of Delaware office locations

community_programs.name: Approved Community-Based Agencies under Standing Order
community_programs.type: harm reduction organizations and health providers
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, overdose education, training on recognition and response
community_programs.eligibility: Community members; training provision required by organizations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Throughout Delaware; specific locations vary by approved agency

mail_based_programs.name: Delaware Division of Public Health Free Naloxone Mail Program
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Any Delaware resident; particularly prioritizes people who use drugs, those recently released from incarceration, friends and family of at-risk individuals
mail_based_programs.notes: Statewide mail program through DHSS in partnership with NEXT Distro national platform. Naloxone mailed discretely; 5-minute online training video required (or in-person training alternative available).

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Naloxone (NEXT Distro affiliate - Delaware DHSS partner)
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, recently incarcerated, family members of at-risk individuals
mail_based_programs.notes: NEXT Distro partners with Delaware Division of Public Health for statewide naloxone distribution. Operates through nextdistro.org with state-specific resources.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Contact Delaware Division of Public Health to request free naloxone by mail (5-minute training required or attend in-person training); attend Naloxone Access Training events offered throughout state by DSAMH; visit participating pharmacies to receive naloxone under standing order; contact Community Collaboration of Delaware SAVE Program; order online through NEXT Distro at nextdistro.org/delaware.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural and small-town access enhanced by statewide mail program at no cost; training requirement (1 hour in-person or 5 minutes online) addressed by multiple training options; cost completely eliminated through state programs. OpiRescue DE app provides additional support and naloxone finder function.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Delaware offers OpiRescue DE smartphone app (free download from Android or Apple stores) with step-by-step naloxone support and resource finder; training videos available; specific multilingual support not documented but state programs encourage accessibility

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Legal and accessible through statewide standing order for emergency responders and healthcare provider prescribing

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Florida Statute 381.887 authorizes pharmacists to dispense emergency opioid antagonists (naloxone, narcan) through statewide standing orders. The Surgeon General issued a statewide Standing Order for Naloxone in September 2022. Pharmacists may dispense naloxone to emergency responders, patients, caregivers, and authorized healthcare practitioners.
key_statutes_or_policies: Florida Surgeon General Statewide Standing Order for Naloxone (September 2022)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Civil immunity for persons acting in good faith who administer opioid antagonists to someone experiencing overdose; includes protection under Florida Good Samaritan Act
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Good Samaritan protection extends to emergency care providers and laypersons; administered naloxone protection enacted in 2019 (HB 221)

pharmacies.mechanism: Florida pharmacists can dispense naloxone under statewide standing order without individual patient prescriptions. Pharmacists may dispense to emergency responders, patients, caregivers, and first responders. Intranasal, prefilled injection, and auto-injection delivery systems available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan $45-49.99 at retail (2-dose pack); prescription naloxone through pharmacies; free narcan through Florida Overdose Prevention Program
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Naloxone covered by Florida Medicaid; free distribution through state Overdose Prevention Program to eligible individuals and organizations

community_programs.name: Florida Department of Children and Families Overdose Prevention Program
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits, overdose recognition and response training; distributed through 600+ enrolled distributors statewide; naloxone provided in FDA-approved formulations
community_programs.eligibility: Individuals at risk of experiencing or witnessing opioid overdose; open to community members
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through 600+ enrolled distributors including substance abuse treatment providers, shelters, hospitals, federally qualified health centers, recovery organizations, colleges, and county health departments (all 67 counties)

community_programs.name: Florida Department of Health County Programs
community_programs.services: Free Narcan distribution, overdose prevention education, naloxone training
community_programs.eligibility: Community members; no restrictions
community_programs.in_person_locations: All 67 county health departments throughout Florida; example: Duval County multiple clinic locations (Jacksonville area and surrounding)

community_programs.name: iSave FL Initiative
community_programs.services: Public awareness of naloxone access, education on use, and resources
community_programs.eligibility: General public
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide awareness and education campaign

mail_based_programs.name: Florida Harm Reduction Collective (NEXT Distro Affiliate)
mail_based_programs.provider_type: state affiliate of national mail-order program
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, recently incarcerated individuals, friends and family members of at-risk individuals; prioritizes those unable to access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.notes: Free naloxone mailed to Florida residents through NEXT Distro partnership with Florida Harm Reduction Collective (joined NEXT partnership December 2019, upgraded to full-service March 2022). Includes overdose prevention education and fentanyl test strips.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any participating Florida pharmacy without prescription (statewide standing order allows immediate dispensing); contact Florida Department of Children and Families Overdose Prevention Program to locate 600+ distributors near you; visit or call local county health department (all 67 counties); use iSaveFL website to find resources; request by mail through NEXT Distro at nextdistro.org/florida.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural area access supported by 600+ statewide network of distributors and all county health departments; cost eliminated through free state program (1.8+ million free kits distributed as of March 2025); pharmacy stigma addressed by knowing standing order authorizes dispensing to anyone requesting. Mail option serves those in remote areas.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: iSaveFL campaign provides public education; county health departments provide services in multiple languages and formats; no specific multilingual naloxone training documentation located but state program emphasis on wide distribution suggests accessibility efforts

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Georgia Code §26-4-116.2 and Georgia Department of Public Health Standing Order for Naloxone authorize licensed practitioners and pharmacies to dispense naloxone to anyone in a position to help a person experiencing opioid overdose. The Commissioner of Public Health (State Health Officer) issues statewide standing orders. Training is advised but not required. Pharmacists may dispense intranasal naloxone (Narcan and generics), intramuscular naloxone with syringe, and auto-injector naloxone.
key_statutes_or_policies: Georgia Department of Public Health Standing Order for Naloxone (2019)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects anyone acting in good faith and with reasonable care who administers naloxone from criminal, civil, and professional licensing liability; physicians and pharmacists also protected for prescribing/dispensing; harm reduction organizations protected for distributing
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Immunity applies regardless of whether naloxone was expired at time of use, if obtained through valid prescription or standing order and administered with reasonable care

pharmacies.mechanism: Georgia pharmacists can dispense naloxone under statewide standing order to anyone without individual prescription. Dispensing authorized for first responders, friends, family members, harm reduction organizations, pain management clinics, and any person in a position to help someone at risk of overdose.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $45 at retail; free naloxone through state programs and community organizations; generic prescription options available at lower cost
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Naloxone covered by Georgia Medicaid; free distribution through state programs and community partners reduces cost barriers

community_programs.name: Georgia Harm Reduction Coalition (GHRC)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone distribution, fentanyl test strips, harm reduction supplies, syringe services, health screening, linkages to medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) and treatment
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and their communities; serves 130 of 159 Georgia counties
community_programs.in_person_locations: Atlanta main office and 7 mobile health units throughout Georgia; serves multiple regions across state

community_programs.name: Georgia Overdose Prevention
community_programs.type: harm reduction and state program partner
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits, overdose prevention training and education, harm reduction services
community_programs.eligibility: High-risk individuals (people actively using drugs, family members of active users); training available for first responders
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide; main operations in Atlanta

community_programs.name: Georgia Department of Behavioral Health and Developmental Disabilities (DBHDD)
community_programs.services: Naloxone bulk distribution to contracted harm reduction providers and community-based organizations; technical assistance and funding for naloxone programs
community_programs.eligibility: Community-based organizations, contracted providers
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide coordination through state agency; implementation via local partners

mail_based_programs.name: Georgia Overdose Prevention - NEXT Distro Affiliate
mail_based_programs.provider_type: state affiliate of national mail-order program
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, recently released individuals, first responders; prioritizes those unable to access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.notes: Free naloxone mailed discretely to Georgia residents through NEXT Distro partnership with Georgia Overdose Prevention (joined NEXT June 2020; upgraded to full-service provider status). Includes overdose education and fentanyl test strips.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Georgia pharmacy and request naloxone under standing order (no prescription needed); contact Georgia Overdose Prevention online form to request free naloxone kit; reach out to Georgia Harm Reduction Coalition for in-person support; visit local harm reduction organizations or health departments; request by mail through NEXT Distro at nextdistro.org/georgia.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural access enhanced by GHRC mobile units serving 130 of 159 counties and mail-based NEXT Distro; cost eliminated through free state programs; training is advised but not required, making naloxone immediately accessible. Language and cultural barriers addressed through GHRC's community-based approach and partnerships.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Georgia Harm Reduction Coalition uses community-based approach and includes engagement with diverse communities; no specific multilingual naloxone training documentation located but statewide coordination through DBHDD suggests attention to accessibility

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is accessible via pharmacist prescriptive authority (Act 154) and OTC availability. Healthcare providers can dispense to anyone at risk or in a position to assist.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Under Act 154 (2018), Hawaii pharmacists can prescribe and dispense naloxone to individuals at risk of overdose, family members, or caregivers without a prescription from a doctor. Pharmacists must complete a training program.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects persons who seek medical assistance for an overdose (themselves or others) from arrest and prosecution for drug possession, paraphernalia, and probation/parole violations.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Immunity applies only if evidence was obtained as a result of seeking medical assistance. Does not protect against felony offenses beyond possession. Act 217 (2015) established this medical amnesty.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists can independently prescribe and dispense naloxone after a brief consultation. Most major chains (Longs/CVS, Walgreens, Safeway) participate.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan ~$45-50; Medicaid (QUEST Integration) covers naloxone with $0 copay.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Hawaii QUEST Integration (Medicaid) covers naloxone fully without prior authorization.

community_programs.name: Hawaii Health & Harm Reduction Center (HHHRC)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits, syringe exchange, fentanyl test strips, overdose prevention training.
community_programs.eligibility: Open to all residents. Specific mail-order focus for neighbor islands.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Honolulu (Oahu); partners on Maui, Hawaii Island, and Kauai.

community_programs.name: Maui AIDS Foundation
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution and harm reduction services.
community_programs.eligibility: Maui residents.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Wailuku, Maui.

community_programs.name: Kumukahi Health + Wellness
community_programs.services: Naloxone and sexual health services.
community_programs.eligibility: Hawaii Island residents.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Hilo and Kailua-Kona.

mail_based_programs.name: HHHRC Mail Distribution
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Residents of Kaua'i, Lana'i, and Moloka'i specifically.
mail_based_programs.notes: Fills gaps where in-person access is difficult on smaller islands.

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs or are close to those who do.
mail_based_programs.notes: Serves as a statewide backup for mail-based access.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Oahu: Visit HHHRC (677 Ala Moana Blvd) or a pharmacy like Longs/CVS. Neighbor Islands: Contact Kumukahi (Big Island) or Maui AIDS Foundation. Rural/Remote: Use HHHRC mail order if on Kaua'i/Lana'i/Moloka'i, otherwise use NEXT Distro.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Geographic isolation on neighbor islands is a major barrier; mail-order programs are designed to mitigate this. Cost at pharmacies can be high without insurance; community programs are free.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Hawaii has high linguistic diversity; HHHRC provides culturally competent care. Translation often available at chain pharmacies.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is available via pharmacist prescriptive authority. Any licensed health professional can prescribe/dispense to anyone.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Idaho Statute 54-1733B allows any licensed health professional (including pharmacists) to prescribe and dispense opioid antagonists to any person or entity. It does not require a patient-specific relationship.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Limited. Protects persons who *administer* naloxone from civil/criminal liability for the act of administration. It does NOT explicitly provide broad immunity for drug possession arrest when reporting an overdose.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Statute 54-1733B(3) provides immunity for the act of prescribing, dispensing, or administering naloxone. Unlike many other states, Idaho lacks a broad 'Medical Amnesty' law that protects the caller from possession charges.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists can independently prescribe and dispense naloxone to anyone. You do not need a doctor's script beforehand.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan ~$45; Free for Medicaid members.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Idaho Medicaid covers naloxone with $0 copay at pharmacies.

community_programs.name: Idaho Harm Reduction Project (IHRP)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone, fentanyl test strips, safe use supplies.
community_programs.eligibility: Open to all Idaho residents.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Boise area; statewide mail distribution.

community_programs.name: Idaho Department of Health & Welfare
community_programs.services: Free naloxone for organizations (schools, libraries, YMCAs) to stock.
community_programs.eligibility: Organizations and entities.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide distribution to partner agencies.

mail_based_programs.name: Idaho Harm Reduction Project / NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and their families.
mail_based_programs.notes: IHRP partners with NEXT Distro to provide discreet mail delivery statewide.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Fastest: Go to a pharmacy (Walgreens/CVS) and ask for naloxone; if you have Medicaid it is free. Free/Anonymous: Contact Idaho Harm Reduction Project for mail delivery or local pickup in Boise.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Good Samaritan laws are weaker here (no possession immunity), so people may hesitate to call 911. Police involvement is a risk. Mail-order is recommended for privacy.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Information primarily in English. Medicaid covers translation services at pharmacies.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Widely available via IDPH Statewide Standing Order. Pharmacists and 'OEND' (Overdose Education and Naloxone Distribution) programs can dispense without a prescription.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) Standing Order allows pharmacies, schools, and registered OEND programs to dispense naloxone. It acts as a non-patient-specific prescription.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects caller and victim from prosecution for felony possession of controlled substances, but with strict quantity limits.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Immunity applies only if the amount possessed is LESS THAN: 3g heroin, 3g cocaine, 3g morphine, 40g prescription opioids/peyote/barbiturates/amphetamines, 3g LSD, or 6g PCP. This is a critical distinction compared to states with unlimited possession immunity.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacies enrolled in the standing order can dispense immediately. Most major chains participate.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan ~$45; Medicaid covers naloxone.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Illinois Medicaid covers naloxone. No copay for preferred products.

community_programs.name: Chicago Recovery Alliance (CRA)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone (injectable and nasal), syringe service program, drug checking.
community_programs.eligibility: Open to all.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Mobile vans throughout Chicago (South and West sides); Silver van schedule available online.

community_programs.name: IDPH Access Narcan
community_programs.services: Provides naloxone to OEND programs (police, fire, health depts, schools).
community_programs.eligibility: Organizations must register as OEND programs.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through registered local health departments.

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro / Chicago Recovery Alliance
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and their families.
mail_based_programs.notes: Partners with CRA to ship statewide.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Chicago: Find a CRA silver van (check schedule) for free supplies. Statewide: Walk into Walgreens/CVS and use the Standing Order. Mail: Use NEXT Distro.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: The Good Samaritan law has quantity limits (3g heroin/cocaine), so carrying large amounts while calling 911 is legally risky. Rural access is improved by the 'Access Narcan' program supplying local health departments.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Chicago Recovery Alliance offers services in Spanish. IDPH materials available in multiple languages.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Legal and accessible via 'Aaron's Law' (SB 406). Statewide standing order allows any entity registered with OptIN to dispense.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Aaron's Law allows laypeople to obtain naloxone without a prescription. The State Health Commissioner issues a standing order that entities (pharmacies, nonprofits, health depts) use to dispense.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects caller from arrest/prosecution for possession of cocaine, methamphetamine, or a controlled substance, and paraphernalia.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Conditions: Must administer naloxone (if available), call 911, remain on scene, cooperate with authorities, and provide full name.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacies registered with OptIN.in.gov can dispense under the standing order.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan ~$45; Free for Medicaid members.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Indiana Medicaid covers naloxone.

community_programs.services: NaloxBox distribution, training, and direct distribution.

community_programs.in_person_locations: Indianapolis and statewide NaloxBox locations.

community_programs.name: Indiana Recovery Alliance
community_programs.services: Mobile syringe exchange and naloxone distribution.
community_programs.eligibility: Open to all.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Bloomington and surrounding areas.

community_programs.services: Registry of all naloxone providers in the state.

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro / ShipHappens
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs.
mail_based_programs.notes: Operated in partnership with ShipHappens.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Check OptIN.in.gov for the nearest registered provider (pharmacy or non-profit). Look for 'NaloxBoxes' (public vending machines) managed by Overdose Lifeline. Visit Indiana Recovery Alliance in Bloomington.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas rely on the OptIN map. Vending machines (NaloxBoxes) provide 24/7 access in some locations to bypass stigma.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: OptIN website is the central hub. Overdose Lifeline provides broad educational resources.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Iowa Code 147A.18 and 135.190 authorize the standing order. Pharmacists can dispense to those at risk, family, friends, or first responders.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Extremely limited 'One-Time' immunity. Protects the reporter from possession charges only if they have not used the immunity before.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Iowa Code 124.418 defines an 'overdose reporter' as someone who has NOT previously received immunity under this section. This means you only get ONE 'free pass' for calling 911 on an overdose in your lifetime regarding possession charges. This is highly restrictive compared to other states.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists dispense under the standing order after a brief assessment. OTC Narcan is also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan ~$45; Medicaid covers naloxone.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Iowa Medicaid covers naloxone.

community_programs.name: Iowa Harm Reduction Coalition (IHRC)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone, syringe exchange, fentanyl test strips, telehealth support.
community_programs.eligibility: Open to all Iowans.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Cedar Rapids, Des Moines, Iowa City, and mobile outreach.

mail_based_programs.name: IHRC Mail Delivery
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Anyone in Iowa can request supplies via text or email.
mail_based_programs.notes: Flexible mail order system via text/email to 319-214-0540.

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs.
mail_based_programs.notes: Partners with IHRC.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Text Iowa Harm Reduction Coalition (319-214-0540) for rapid support or mail delivery. Walk into pharmacies for OTC Narcan.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: The 'One-Time' Good Samaritan immunity is a dangerous legal trap; be aware that calling 911 a second time may result in arrest if drugs are present. Anonymous reporting or cleaning the scene (if safe/possible) is often discussed in harm reduction circles due to this law.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: IHRC provides low-barrier, judgment-free access via text, bypassing some language/social anxiety barriers.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Legally available to any Kansas resident at risk of opioid overdose, family/friends, first responders, school nurses, and scientists without individual prescription

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Kansas state law and Board of Pharmacy standing order/protocol authorize pharmacists to dispense naloxone nasal spray to anyone believed to be at risk or in position to assist someone at risk. Kansas state will deliver free Narcan kits to Kansas residents upon request.
key_statutes_or_policies: Kansas Board of Pharmacy statewide protocol
KDADS (Kansas Department of Aging and Disability Services) naloxone program

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Kansas has no civilian drug intervention good samaritan laws; however, general emergency assistance protections may apply
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Kansas notably lacks a specific Good Samaritan law for drug overdose emergencies, which is a significant gap in legal protections for people seeking help

pharmacies.mechanism: Statewide protocol allows CVS, Walgreens, Kroger pharmacies and other participating Kansas pharmacies to dispense naloxone without individual prescription to anyone who requests it
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan nasal spray (brand) approximately $44-50 per twin pack; uninsured/cash pay typical pharmacy cost $45-111; Medicaid coverage varies
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Naloxone is covered by Kansas Medicaid; copayment amounts vary by plan, typically $0-3

community_programs.name: Kansas Naloxone Program (DCCCA)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone nasal spray, fentanyl test strips, overdose prevention education and training
community_programs.eligibility: Any Kansas resident or community organization
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide distribution via DCCCA and community partners; DCCCA is primary distributor

mail_based_programs.name: DCCCA Naloxone Kit Request
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Any Kansas resident
mail_based_programs.cost: Free naloxone kit mailed by Kansas state
mail_based_programs.notes: Direct state mail program; free Narcan kits delivered to Kansas residents; also provides fentanyl test strips and training materials

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Walk into any Kansas pharmacy (CVS, Walgreens, Kroger, independent pharmacies) and ask for naloxone nasal spray without a prescription; it's in stock at most major chains. For free naloxone, contact DCCCA at https://www.dccca.org or request a free kit directly from KDADS. State will mail a free kit to any Kansas resident.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural Kansas residents may face pharmacy access challenges; however, the free state mail-based program removes cost barriers for all. No Good Samaritan law in Kansas creates hesitation to call 911; workaround is to emphasize to community members that calling for help is still the safest option despite legal uncertainty. Stigma and awareness gaps remain significant.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: DCCCA provides training and materials; check directly with DCCCA for Spanish or other language support. Fentanyl test strips also available through state program. No specific accessibility statement found; contact DCCCA for ADA accommodations.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Kentucky law authorizes pharmacists and licensed healthcare providers to dispense naloxone to individuals at risk and 'any person or agency who voluntarily requests naloxone' without individual prescription

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Kentucky protocol (sample standing order updated September 28, 2021) allows physicians and pharmacists to enter into naloxone protocols/standing orders. Pharmacists may dispense naloxone without individual prescription under protocol authority. Standing order is not statewide but individual arrangement-based.
key_statutes_or_policies: Kentucky pharmacy protocol for naloxone dispensing
Sample Naloxone Protocol and Education Sheets (Kentucky Board of Pharmacy)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects individuals who call 911 or seek help for someone experiencing an opioid overdose from prosecution for possession/use of controlled substances (non-violent drug crimes); protects both the caller and the person experiencing overdose
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Enacted 2015; must seek help in good faith and remain at scene as required by law; does not protect from other crimes or outstanding warrants

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacies participate in Kentucky naloxone protocol system. Pharmacists under protocol may dispense naloxone to anyone requesting. FindNaloxoneNowKY.org locator lists 136+ locations where naloxone is available
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan nasal spray $44-50 per twin pack; prescription-based costs vary; some pharmacies participate in copay assistance programs; some free through health dept programs
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Kentucky Medicaid covers naloxone; copayment may be $1-4 depending on plan (generic vs brand-name); some copay assistance programs available

community_programs.name: Kentucky Opioid Response Effort (KORE)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone nasal spray (4mg) to agencies and individuals; no cost to recipients; overdose education and training
community_programs.eligibility: KORE-funded agencies, HEALing Communities Study agencies, other Kentucky agencies, and individuals seeking naloxone
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through partnering local health departments and health centers; use FindNaloxoneNowKY.org to locate nearest provider

community_programs.name: Kentucky Harm Reduction Coalition (KyHRC)
community_programs.services: Syringe service program partnerships, overdose prevention, naloxone distribution, fentanyl test strips, xylazine test strips
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, communities impacted by overdose
community_programs.in_person_locations: Louisville-based with outreach statewide; call for current locations

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro - Kentucky Harm Reduction Coalition
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order naloxone program / state partner
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, recently released from jail/prison, people likely to be first responders to overdose who cannot access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.notes: Partnership with Kentucky Harm Reduction Coalition (KyHRC) manages mail distribution; includes fentanyl test strips; no training quiz required but education materials provided; discreet packaging

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Use FindNaloxoneNowKY.org online locator to find 136+ pharmacy and community locations near you offering free or low-cost naloxone. Most CVS and Walgreens pharmacies stock OTC Narcan for ~$45-50. For free naloxone, contact KORE through your local health department or call Kentucky Harm Reduction Coalition.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural counties in eastern and western Kentucky may have limited in-person pharmacy access; use mail-based NEXT Distro service if local access is difficult. Cost historically was a barrier; OTC availability and Medicaid coverage now remove this for most. Stigma and awareness remain barriers; community SSPs are expanding access through trusted local partners.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: FindNaloxoneNowKY.org offers training materials in multiple formats; check with individual providers for language-specific support. KORE and KyHRC can provide accommodation information upon contact.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Louisiana law authorizes licensed medical practitioners and pharmacists to dispense naloxone to any person at risk of opioid overdose or in position to assist, family members, first responders, and others without individual prescription via standing order

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Louisiana Department of Health issued statewide standing order (December 30, 2021; renewed annually April 1, 2025) authorizing licensed pharmacists to dispense naloxone nasal spray to any individual after receiving training. Training requirements include recognizing overdose signs, naloxone administration, and emergency procedures. Laypeople must receive basic education when dispensing naloxone.
key_statutes_or_policies: Louisiana Department of Health Naloxone Standing Order (renewed 2025)
Standing Protocol for Administration of Naloxone

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects individuals and bystanders who call 911 for someone experiencing opioid overdose from prosecution for possession/use of controlled substances; protects both the caller and person experiencing overdose; also protects from alcohol-related charges when seeking help
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Enacted 2022 with amendment to failure-to-assist statute; must act in good faith and seek immediate medical assistance; does not protect from trafficking/distribution charges or other serious crimes

pharmacies.mechanism: Statewide standing order from Louisiana Department of Health allows all licensed pharmacists to dispense naloxone nasal spray (4mg) to anyone after providing brief training on recognition, administration, and emergency response. Participating pharmacies include major chains and independents throughout Louisiana.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan nasal spray $44-50 per twin pack; Louisiana Medicaid covers naloxone with no copayment; uninsured individuals can access free naloxone through programs below
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Louisiana Medicaid covers naloxone with no copayment; this provides critical access for eligible residents

community_programs.name: Louisiana Statewide Overdose Prevention and Response Hub
community_programs.type: state-directed distribution hub and OEND program
community_programs.services: Free naloxone (Narcan 4mg nasal spray), fentanyl test strips, fact sheets; organizations can register as distribution sites; training and educational materials
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and general public; any registered distribution site can order
community_programs.in_person_locations: Centralized portal for statewide ordering; distribution through registered sites across Louisiana regions

community_programs.name: Philadelphia Center - Region 7 SSP
community_programs.type: syringe service program / harm reduction org
community_programs.services: Syringe services, naloxone distribution, fentanyl test strips, overdose prevention education
community_programs.eligibility: People who inject drugs and those at risk
community_programs.in_person_locations: 2020 Centenary Blvd., Shreveport, LA 71104 (Caddo Parish)

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro - Trystereo (Louisiana affiliate)
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order naloxone program with state partner
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, those at risk, family/friends; anyone who cannot access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.cost: Free naloxone (intramuscular or RiVive nasal spray)
mail_based_programs.notes: Partnership with Trystereo (all-volunteer collective, Louisiana's largest naloxone distributor); includes training video and short quiz; available in English and Spanish; discreet packaging; fentanyl test strips also available; no HIPAA-compliant enrollment

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Walk into any Louisiana pharmacy and ask for naloxone nasal spray under the statewide standing order; most pharmacists will provide brief training and dispense immediately. For free access, contact the Louisiana Overdose Prevention and Response Hub (louisianahealthhub.org) or a nearby SSP. NEXT Distro / Trystereo mails free naloxone to your home within 1 week if local access is difficult.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural Louisiana parishes may have limited pharmacy access; mail-based Trystereo program removes this barrier. Cost is low/eliminated for Medicaid beneficiaries and through free programs. Stigma is mitigated by pharmacy-based access and community SSPs integrated into trusted organizations. Training requirement can be addressed online through NEXT Distro.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: NEXT Distro/Trystereo offers training video, quiz, and enrollment in both English and Spanish. Louisiana Overdose Prevention Hub provides materials in multiple languages upon request; contact providers directly for ADA accommodations.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Maine law allows licensed healthcare professionals and pharmacists with standing orders from physicians to dispense naloxone to anyone at risk of opioid overdose or in position to assist without individual prescription; third-party access fully authorized

standing_order_or_protocol.description: No statewide standing order. Instead, individual Maine physicians can issue standing orders to pharmacists authorizing naloxone dispensing. Overdose prevention programs may also operate under standing orders. Maine Access Points (primary harm reduction distributor) operates state-wide NEXT Distro partnership and direct dispensing to anyone needing naloxone.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Maine's Good Samaritan law (2022) provides broad protection: individuals who call 911 for overdose emergency are protected from arrest and prosecution for ALL non-violent drug crimes (not just possession/use); extends to those experiencing the overdose as well
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: One of the broadest Good Samaritan protections in the country; enacted 2022; does not protect from violent crimes or trafficking; caller must report in good faith

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacies with standing orders from physicians can dispense naloxone without individual prescription. Maine Access Points and partner pharmacies stock naloxone. Pharmacists can dispense under physician-issued standing order arrangements throughout the state.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan nasal spray $44-50 per twin pack; prescription-based costs vary; many Maine residents access free naloxone through state programs; Medicaid coverage available
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Maine Medicaid covers naloxone; copayment varies by plan, typically $0-3; many free community programs eliminate cost entirely

community_programs.name: Maine Access Points (MAP)
community_programs.type: harm reduction organization / primary state distributor
community_programs.services: Free naloxone nasal spray with overdose prevention education and training; syringe access services; peer support; statewide distribution network
community_programs.eligibility: Anyone in Maine; prioritizes people who use drugs and close friends/family
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through tiered distribution network: Portland Public Health (Southern Maine), Bangor Public Health (Northern/Downeast), MaineGeneral Medical Center (Central/Midcoast), and Maine Access Points (statewide peer distribution). 480+ secondary distribution sites as of 2023.

community_programs.name: Maine Naloxone Distribution Initiative (MNDI)
community_programs.services: Coordinated statewide naloxone distribution through tiered network; training and education; harm reduction collaboration
community_programs.eligibility: All Maine residents; special focus on vulnerable and rural populations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Four Tier 1 distributors serving all Maine regions; 480+ Tier 2 community organizations and individuals; over 384,500 naloxone doses distributed to date with 7,173+ reported reversals

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro - Maine Access Points
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order naloxone program with state affiliate
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, family/friends, anyone in Maine unable to access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.notes: Partnership with Maine Access Points (MAP) as NEXT Distro's Maine statewide affiliate; includes fentanyl test strips option; online quiz/training; discreet packaging; call or text 207-319-8284 for direct assistance

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Call or text Maine Access Points at 207-319-8284 (English/Spanish) for free naloxone with training; available statewide with rapid distribution. Visit https://www.maineaccesspoints.org/naloxone to order online. Walk into pharmacies in Portland, Bangor, and other cities to access naloxone directly; most cooperating pharmacies stock it. For mail delivery, use NEXT Distro/Maine Access Points partnership online form.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural Maine (western mountains, Downeast coast) has significant geographic barriers; Maine Access Points' tiered distribution network and mail program specifically designed to reach rural areas. Cost is eliminated through free state programs. Stigma is addressed by peer-driven Maine Access Points model and community-integrated SSP approach.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Maine Access Points provides services in English and Spanish. Maine Naloxone Distribution Initiative emphasizes accessibility and works with rural and underserved communities; contact providers directly for specific ADA accommodations or non-English materials.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Maryland law allows licensed pharmacists and healthcare providers to dispense naloxone to persons at risk for opioid overdose, those who know someone at risk, first responders, school personnel, and correctional staff without individual prescription via statewide standing order

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Maryland Department of Health (MDH) issued statewide standing order (effective June 1, 2021; renewed and expanded under STOP Act 2022) authorizing all Maryland-licensed pharmacists to dispense naloxone including necessary administration supplies to any individual. Standing order allows dispensing from both in-person brick-and-mortar pharmacies and mail-order pharmacies. EMS clinicians also have separate standing order for naloxone leave-behind program.
key_statutes_or_policies: Maryland Statewide Naloxone Standing Order (MDH Deputy Secretary, renewed 2023-2024)
Maryland Statewide Targeted Overdose Prevention (STOP) Act of 2022 (SB 394)
EMS Naloxone Leave-Behind Protocol Standing Order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Maryland Good Samaritan law (2013, strengthened 2015 and 2022) protects individuals age-unrestricted who call 911 for opioid overdose from arrest/prosecution for possession/use of controlled substances and drug paraphernalia; also protects from providing alcohol to minors charge; protects both caller and person experiencing overdose
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Enacted 2013, strengthened 2015 (SB 654/HB 1009) and 2022 (STOP Act); broad protective scope; does not protect outstanding warrants or other crimes; calling 911 does not affect parole/probation status

pharmacies.mechanism: Statewide standing order allows all Maryland-licensed pharmacists (including mail-order) to dispense naloxone to any individual without prescription or age restriction. Major pharmacy chains (CVS, Walgreens, Target pharmacies) and independent pharmacies stock naloxone throughout Maryland.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan nasal spray $44-50 per twin pack; many uninsured/low-income residents access free naloxone through community programs; Maryland Medicaid covers naloxone with no or minimal copayment
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Maryland Medicaid covers naloxone with copayment varying $0-$4 depending on plan; no-copayment naloxone available through state programs for eligible individuals

community_programs.name: Staying Alive Overdose Response Program (Baltimore City)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone dispensing with overdose prevention education; EMS naloxone leave-behind; spike response outreach with rapid distribution to areas with overdose clusters
community_programs.eligibility: Baltimore City residents; anyone present during overdose emergency
community_programs.in_person_locations: Through MDH-registered Overdose Response Programs and Syringe Service Programs throughout Baltimore City; EMS-assisted through fire department

community_programs.name: Maryland Overdose Response Programs (Statewide)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone, fentanyl test strips, overdose prevention education and training through community-based programs
community_programs.eligibility: All Maryland residents; special focus on people at highest risk
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide network of MDH-registered ORPs and SSPs; contact health department for program locator

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro - Baltimore Harm Reduction Coalition
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order naloxone program with state affiliate
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Maryland residents; people who use drugs, family/friends, anyone unable to access naloxone locally
mail_based_programs.cost: Free naloxone (intramuscular and nasal spray options)
mail_based_programs.notes: Partnership with Baltimore Harm Reduction Coalition (joined NEXT January 2020); includes fentanyl test strips; online training/quiz required; available in English and Spanish; discreet packaging; mail delivery within 1 week typical

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Walk into any Maryland pharmacy (CVS, Walgreens, Target, independent pharmacies) and ask for naloxone nasal spray; no prescription needed under statewide standing order. For free naloxone with training, contact Baltimore Health Department or find a local Overdose Response Program through health.maryland.gov. NEXT Distro/Baltimore Harm Reduction Coalition mails free naloxone and fentanyl test strips to your home if you fill out online form.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Urban-rural divide in pharmacy access; mail-based NEXT Distro serves rural Maryland effectively. Cost removed through free programs and Medicaid coverage. Stigma mitigated by pharmacy-based access, health department programs, and community-embedded SSPs integrated into trusted organizations.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: NEXT Distro/Baltimore Harm Reduction Coalition offers enrollment in English and Spanish. Maryland Department of Health provides materials in multiple languages; contact providers directly for specific accessibility needs or non-English support.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: A statewide standing order authorizes licensed pharmacists to dispense naloxone rescue kits to any person at risk of overdose, or to family/friends in a position to assist, without a patient-specific prescription.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protects overdose victims and those seeking help in good faith from prosecution for possession of controlled substances and violations of probation, parole, or pretrial release.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Does not offer immunity for trafficking, distribution, or other non-drug crimes.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists dispense under the statewide standing order; insurance often covers the cost (copays vary).

community_programs.name: Community Naloxone Program (CNP)
