community_programs.eligibility: Organizations serving high-risk populations (shelters, treatment centers) can apply to distribute.
community_programs.in_person_locations: Various affiliated agencies across the state (Boston, Worcester, Springfield).

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro Massachusetts

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Go to any major pharmacy (CVS, Walgreens) and request it at the counter under the standing order; many insurance plans cover it fully. Alternatively, contact a local syringe service program for a free anonymous kit.

practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: MassHealth provides strong support; many urban programs offer Spanish/Portuguese services.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal and accessible without individual patient prescription through standing order and direct pharmacist prescribing authority. OTC nasal spray (Narcan) also available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: New Mexico State Health Officer issued statewide standing order authorizing registered pharmacists to dispense naloxone to any person at risk of opioid overdose or any person in a position to assist someone at risk. Pharmacists have independent prescribing authority for naloxone under expanded authority.
key_statutes_or_policies: New Mexico Statewide Standing Order for Registered Pharmacist Dispensing of Naloxone
New Mexico Health Care Authority coverage under Centennial Care (Medicaid)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: First person seeking emergency medical assistance and the person experiencing overdose are protected from arrest, prosecution, and charges for possession of controlled substances and drug paraphernalia. First responders and naloxone administrators also protected.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: New Mexico enacted first Good Samaritan overdose law in 2007 (NM Stat. Ann. 1978, §31-18-15.1). Immunity applies broadly when 911 is called.

pharmacies.mechanism: Statewide standing order from New Mexico State Health Officer authorizes all registered pharmacists to dispense naloxone without individual patient prescription to anyone at risk or in position to assist. OTC Narcan also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (nasal spray): approximately $45 for 2-dose pack at retail. Generic naloxone with atomizer: $20-$40 range at many pharmacies.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Centennial Care (New Mexico Medicaid) covers naloxone fully with no copayment. Reimbursement includes medication cost plus $3.65 dispensing fee and $37.50 incentive payment for pharmacists.

community_programs.type: state-based harm reduction training and distribution
community_programs.services: Free virtual naloxone training and administration education; free naloxone kits and harm reduction supplies mailed upon completion of one-hour training
community_programs.eligibility: All New Mexico residents; open to general public
community_programs.in_person_locations: Virtual program with statewide mail delivery; partnerships across 33 counties and Pueblo/Tribal communities

community_programs.type: national mail-based harm reduction organization with local partners
community_programs.services: Free naloxone by mail; fentanyl test strips; sterile syringe supplies; online overdose prevention training
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs, recently released individuals, high-risk individuals, family/friends
community_programs.in_person_locations: Mail-based; local partner organizations throughout state

community_programs.name: New Mexico Department of Health - Opioid Resources
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution coordination; training materials; community provider resources
community_programs.eligibility: All residents; healthcare providers; community organizations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through county health departments and partner agencies

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and those connected to them; prioritizes those at direct risk of overdose
mail_based_programs.notes: No online quiz required; enrollment form for mailing. Provides naloxone kits with training materials. Over 30 harm reduction organizations partner with NEXT Distro nationwide.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Call any pharmacy in New Mexico and ask for naloxone under the statewide standing order—no prescription needed. OTC Narcan ($45) available immediately at CVS, Walgreens, Rite Aid, and other retailers. For free naloxone: enroll in CORE program online (iECHO portal) for virtual training, then receive free kit by mail. Contact local county health department or call NCHRC for in-person access.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural access can be limited; mail-based NEXT Distro addresses this. Cost ($45 OTC) may be prohibitive for uninsured/underinsured—use free state programs (CORE, NEXT Distro) or Medicaid (free). Stigma at pharmacies: ask for naloxone by standing order rather than by name to reduce perceived judgment. Opioid treatment centers and harm reduction organizations provide free training with distribution.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Spanish-language materials available through state health department. CORE program uses iECHO platform which supports multiple accessibility features.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal and accessible without individual patient prescription. Broad access through standing orders and pharmacist dispensing. OTC nasal spray (Narcan) available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: New York State has established standing orders allowing pharmacists to dispense naloxone to anyone without a prescription. Both direct pharmacist dispensing and community OEND program standing orders are authorized. Over 1,000 registered OEND programs distribute naloxone statewide.
key_statutes_or_policies: Public Health Law Article 30 (Good Samaritan provisions)
New York Pharmacist Naloxone Standing Orders

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Any person acting in good faith without gross negligence who renders emergency medical assistance, including naloxone administration, to someone experiencing or appearing to experience opioid overdose receives immunity from civil liability. Protects both helper and overdose victim.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Broad protection under Public Health Law §3000-d; applies to lay responders and medical professionals. Protection extends to property owners allowing naloxone use on premises.

pharmacies.mechanism: Statewide standing orders and New York pharmacist prescribing authority allow any pharmacist to dispense naloxone without individual patient prescription. OTC Narcan also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (nasal spray): approximately $45 for 2-dose pack. Insurance copays vary; generic naloxone typically $0-$4 with Medicaid.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: New York Medicaid FFS covers naloxone; managed care plans cover through their formularies. No copayment typical for Medicaid beneficiaries. Dual-eligible covered through Medicare Part D.

mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and connected individuals; prioritizes direct users and recently released individuals
mail_based_programs.notes: No quiz required; enrollment via website or direct contact. NYC-specific page with local resources. Over 30 partner organizations nationwide including New York programs.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any New York pharmacy and ask for naloxone—standing orders allow dispensing without prescription. For immediate OTC access: buy Narcan ($45) at any CVS, Walgreens, Rite Aid, or other major pharmacy. For free naloxone: locate nearest OEND program via health.ny.gov or NEXT Distro. NYC residents can use STOP NYC OD app to find pharmacy partners and community programs. Mail-based option through NEXT Distro takes 2-4 weeks.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Stigma may discourage pharmacy visits—OEND programs offer confidential, non-judgmental access. Cost ($45 OTC) mitigated by 1,000+ free community programs and Medicaid coverage. Rural upstate access challenges addressed through NEXT Distro mail program. Recent incarceration history accommodated by OEND programs with peer services.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Multilingual support available through NYC health department and many community OEND programs; Spanish, Mandarin, Cantonese, and other languages represented. STOP NYC OD app available in multiple languages.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Call North Dakota Department of Human Services (701-328-8920) to request free Narcan by mail (5-7 business days). Visit any North Dakota pharmacy and ask for naloxone—pharmacists can dispense without prescription. Buy OTC Narcan ($45) immediately at CVS, Walgreens, or other retailers. Contact local county health department (Bismarck-Burleigh, Grand Forks) for same-week naloxone access.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural sparse population addressed through mail-order programs and county health department coordination. Cost ($45 OTC) offset by free state and local programs. Limited pharmacy network in remote areas mitigated by state mail program and NEXT Distro. Stigma reduced through health department-run programs rather than law enforcement.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Limited specific language support information found; state programs likely coordinate with local translators. Rural accessibility prioritized through mail delivery and phone-based request system.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Ohio law allows pharmacists to dispense naloxone without individual patient prescription when operating under a standing order from a licensed physician. good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Person seeking emergency medical assistance, person assisting that person, and overdose victim are protected from arrest, prosecution, and charges for possession of controlled substances or drug paraphernalia when 911 is called and followed up with law enforcement assistance.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Ohio Revised Code §2925.55 (enacted 2016). Broad protection when 911 is called. Applies to emergency assistance seekers and victims equally.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists dispensing under standing order from licensed physician (common arrangement in Ohio). OTC Narcan also available.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit nearest hospital emergency department participating in Project DAWN for free naloxone kit and training (same-day access). Contact county health department to locate Project DAWN sites by county. Call local law enforcement to inquire about naloxone leave-behind programs. Buy OTC Narcan ($45) at any CVS, Walgreens, or pharmacy chain. Mail-based access through NEXT Distro takes 2-3 weeks.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural access facilitated through county health department networks and law enforcement partnerships. Cost ($45 OTC) eliminated through Project DAWN's statewide free program. Stigma reduced through hospital and health department-based distribution rather than relying solely on criminal legal system. Street-outreach based programs also available in urban areas.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Ohio hospital systems provide multilingual staff at Project DAWN sites; specific language services vary by location. ODH materials available in English.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Oklahoma law directly authorizes participating pharmacies to dispense naloxone without prescription or standing order requirement. Statewide standing order also in effect. Oklahoma Department of Mental Health and Substance Abuse Services (ODMHSAS) coordinates distribution through vending machines, online ordering, and community partners.
key_statutes_or_policies: Oklahoma statute authorizing pharmacist naloxone dispensing without prescription

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Protection applies only to individuals seeking assistance for others experiencing overdose (not to victims themselves). Protects person calling 911 and assisting person from prosecution for controlled substance possession when seeking medical help for overdose victim.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Oklahoma Good Samaritan law (enacted 2013) uniquely limits protection to helpers/seekers; does not extend to overdose victim. This is more restrictive than many states.

pharmacies.mechanism: Participating pharmacies authorized to dispense naloxone without prescription directly or under standing order. No pharmacy-specific prescription requirement. OTC Narcan also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (nasal spray): approximately $45 for 2-dose pack. Pharmacy dispensing: likely free or minimal copay.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Oklahoma Medicaid covers naloxone; copayment amount unclear per NEXT Distro data. Recommend contacting insurance provider or using free state programs.

mail_based_programs.notes: Enrollment via website. Provides naloxone with harm reduction education materials. Complements state okimready.org program.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Order free Narcan online at okimready.org (ships within 1 week with 5 doses and optional fentanyl test strips). Check vending machine locator at okimready.org for 40 locations with free Narcan kits (immediate in-person access). Visit participating pharmacy to request naloxone without prescription. Buy OTC Narcan ($45) at CVS, Walgreens, Rite Aid, or online retailers. Email overdose.prevention@odmhsas.org for additional resources or community partner information.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Cost completely eliminated through okimready.org free program and 40 vending machines (largest US initiative). Rural access: vending machines placed strategically in high-overdose-prevalence areas; online ordering ships statewide. Stigma: vending machine access and online ordering remove pharmacy/person-to-person contact. Good Samaritan law limitation (doesn't protect victims) mitigated by calling 911 anyway for medical help.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: okimready.org appears English-only; ODMHSAS may provide Spanish language materials upon request. Vending machines provide immediate non-linguistic access.

standing_order_or_protocol.type: statewide standing order and collaborative practice agreements
standing_order_or_protocol.description: Pennsylvania Department of Health issues statewide standing order (most recent update May 2025) authorizing pharmacists to dispense naloxone without individual patient prescription. Statewide standing order valid for both prescription and OTC naloxone products. May 2025 update added 3mg naloxone nasal spray (RiVive) and created tiered standing order.
key_statutes_or_policies: Pennsylvania Act 139 of 2014 (Controlled Substance, Drug, Device and Cosmetic Act)
PA Department of Health General Public Standing Order (updated May 2025)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Person calling 911 receives immunity from prosecution for controlled substance possession charges when reporting overdose. Immunity contingent on person remaining with victim and cooperating with law enforcement. Victim's immunity is contingent on caller's immunity.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Pennsylvania Statute §4223 (enacted 2014). Requires caller to provide identifying information to emergency services and remain on scene. 'Contingent immunity' creates complexity for overdose victims.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pennsylvania Department of Health statewide standing order (updated May 2025) authorizes pharmacists to dispense naloxone without individual prescription. Tiered standing order guides toward most effective formulations but maintains access to all approved forms. OTC Narcan also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (nasal spray): approximately $45 for 2-dose pack. Pharmacy dispensing under standing order: Free for Medicaid; copay assistance available through PACE copay assistance program (up to $75/claim).
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Pennsylvania Medicaid recipients with prescription coverage: naloxone products at no cost. Copay Assistance Program (PACE) available for those without coverage or after insurance limits; covers up to $75 per claim for eligible naloxone products on PA Dept of Health standing order.

mail_based_programs.provider_type: state mail-order program with NEXT Distro partnership (since 2020)
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Pennsylvania residents; people at risk of overdose; family/friends; people recently released from prison
mail_based_programs.notes: Requires online training video and short quiz through NEXT platform, then enrollment form. Plain bubble mailer shipping. Enrollment info not HIPAA compliant per privacy policy but secured under NEXT protocols. Philadelphia-specific separate access page available.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Pennsylvania pharmacy with PA Department of Health standing order (no prescription needed); standing order valid for all naloxone products including OTC formulations. Buy OTC Narcan ($45) immediately at CVS, Walgreens, Rite Aid, or online retailers. Contact local Centralized Coordinating Entity (CCE) for free organizational naloxone kits. Mail-to-home: complete online training/quiz on NEXT Distro website, enroll, receive kit within 2 weeks. For copay assistance: contact PACE program at BIN 002286, PCN 0000682201 (covers up to $75).
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Cost: No-cost pharmacy access through standing order; OTC $45; mail-to-home free; PACE assistance covers additional copay costs (up to $75). Medicaid recipients: no-cost pharmacy access. Contingent immunity in Good Samaritan law (victim's protection depends on caller) is complex—always call 911 for medical emergency. Rural access: mail-to-home program addresses pharmacy deserts. Stigma: standing order eliminates need to ask prescriber; mail program provides confidential access.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Pennsylvania Department of Health materials available in multiple languages. Community providers and mail-to-home program can accommodate accessibility requests; contact directly.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Rhode Island law authorizes pharmacists operating under collaborative practice agreements (standing orders from licensed prescribers) to dispense naloxone without individual patient prescription. Community-based and mail-based programs also authorized to distribute naloxone without prescription.

Prevent Overdose RI - Statewide Harm Reduction Coordination
University of Rhode Island Community First Responder Program

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: First person calling for emergency medical assistance and person assisting that person, as well as overdose victim, are protected from prosecution for drug possession and related charges. Broad protection applies when emergency services are contacted.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Rhode Island provides comprehensive good samaritan protections. Protections include immunity from supervision status violations (e.g., parole/probation violations) in addition to criminal charges.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists dispensing under collaborative practice agreements (standing orders from prescribers). OTC Narcan also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (nasal spray): approximately $45 for 2-dose pack. Pharmacy dispensing: varies by insurance; Medicaid fully covers.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Rhode Island Medicaid fully covers generic naloxone and brand name single-step intranasal spray (including new RiVive). All health insurers cover at least one naloxone type with no-cost or low-cost copayment. Copay assistance available where applicable.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Call Providence Drop-in (401-383-4888) or Pawtucket Drop-in (401-867-2662) for same-day free naloxone (open Mon-Fri). Visit any Rhode Island pharmacy to request naloxone under collaborative practice agreement. Buy OTC Narcan ($45) at CVS, Walgreens, or online retailers. Complete online training via University of Rhode Island or Prevent Overdose RI website, then request mail-based naloxone (delivers within 1 week). Downtown Mobile Outreach at Kennedy Plaza (Mon-Fri 10am-2pm) for street-based access.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Cost: All insurers cover with low/no copay; Medicaid fully covers; free through drop-in centers and mail programs. Urban accessibility excellent (3 drop-in sites). Rural/statewide: mail-based programs (URI CFRP, NEXT Distro) and Prevent Overdose RI coordination. Stigma: university-affiliated CFRP and community drop-in model provide non-judgmental access. Comprehensive good samaritan protection (including parole/probation immunity) removes legal barriers.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Prevent Overdose RI website provides resources in multiple languages. Drop-in centers have staff multilingual capacity; contact to arrange. URI CFRP online training accessible with various screen reader/accessibility tools.

South Carolina Joint Protocol to Initiate Dispensing of Naloxone HCl Without a Prescription

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: First person calling for emergency medical assistance AND person assisting that person AND overdose victim all protected from arrest and prosecution. However, protection is limited to first caller (not bystanders); immunity does not apply if caller leaves scene.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: South Carolina Overdose Prevention Act §44-130-10 et seq. (2015, amended 2016). Unusually restrictive: 'first caller' requirement and immunity contingent on remaining on scene and cooperating with law enforcement.

pharmacies.mechanism: Joint Protocol authorizes pharmacists to dispense naloxone without individual prescription. Pharmacist required to document informed consent and provide Notice to Primary Care Provider (if identified). OTC Narcan also available.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan (nasal spray): approximately $45 for 2-dose pack. Pharmacy dispensing: varies; Medicaid typically covered with copay.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: South Carolina Medicaid covers naloxone with copay structure: preferred drugs typically $4 copay, non-preferred $8 copay. Coverage available through outpatient pharmacy benefit.

community_programs.name: South Carolina Overdose Prevention Project (DAODAS)
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution through approved community distributors; first responder training; overdose education; community partnerships
community_programs.eligibility: Varies by community distributor; generally open to at-risk populations and community members
community_programs.in_person_locations: 55+ approved Community Distributors statewide (county alcohol and drug abuse authorities, OTPs, recovery orgs, community organizations)

community_programs.name: South Carolina Harm Reduction Coalition (SCHRC)
community_programs.type: statewide harm reduction advocacy and resource organization
community_programs.services: Advocacy for harm reduction policies; resource development; coalition building; education on naloxone access rights
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs; family members; healthcare providers; community advocates
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide advocacy and coordination; partners with local organizations

community_programs.name: Community Distributors Network (55+ sites statewide)
community_programs.services: Free naloxone distribution; overdose prevention training; community outreach
community_programs.eligibility: People at risk of overdose; family/friends; community members
community_programs.in_person_locations: County alcohol/drug abuse authorities, opioid treatment programs, recovery organizations, community coalitions across SC counties

community_programs.name: NEXT Distro
community_programs.services: Free naloxone by mail; fentanyl test strips; sterile supplies
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and connected individuals
community_programs.in_person_locations: Mail-based statewide

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and connected individuals; prioritizes direct users
mail_based_programs.notes: Enrollment via website form. No online training requirement. Provides naloxone kits with harm reduction education materials.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Contact nearest South Carolina Community Distributor (via DAODAS website link) for free naloxone and training (same-week access). Visit any South Carolina pharmacy to request naloxone under Joint Protocol; pharmacist required to provide informed consent form and Notice to Primary Care Provider. Buy OTC Narcan ($45) at CVS, Walgreens, Rite Aid, or other chain pharmacies. Mail-based access through NEXT Distro takes 2-3 weeks.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Cost ($45 OTC) mitigated by 55+ community distributor sites providing free naloxone. Limited third-party prescribing (caregiver only, not general public) is restrictive compared to other states—rely on pharmacy Joint Protocol access instead. Good Samaritan law 'first caller' requirement is strict; always call 911 and remain on scene. Community distributor network addresses rural access. Stigma reduced through community-based distribution.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: South Carolina community distributors and DAODAS may provide materials in Spanish and other languages; contact regional distributor for accessibility accommodations.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer with standing order or prescription. Codified laws allow pharmacists and healthcare providers to dispense naloxone to anyone at risk of opioid overdose or in a position to assist.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: South Dakota has a statewide standing order issued by the South Dakota Department of Health and Social Services. Pharmacists may dispense naloxone to any person at risk of opioid-related overdose or anyone in a position to assist someone at risk, without a prescription. Recipients must receive verbal and written education about overdose signs, response steps, and naloxone use.
key_statutes_or_policies: South Dakota Department of Health and Social Services standing order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: South Dakota law does not specifically address layperson immunity in statute for opioid-related overdose.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Healthcare providers prescribing or dispensing naloxone have civil, criminal, and disciplinary immunity. No explicit layperson immunity for administration.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists operating under the statewide standing order can dispense naloxone to any eligible person without a patient-specific prescription. Pharmacies must maintain records and provide patient education materials.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan nasal spray costs approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon or generic naloxone; retail price typically $100-120. Many pharmacies participate in the standing order program.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: South Dakota Medicaid covers naloxone. No copay barriers documented. Nasal spray formulation is covered on preferred drug list.

community_programs.name: South Dakota Department of Health OEND Program
community_programs.type: state health department overdose education and naloxone distribution
community_programs.services: Free naloxone kits distributed to organizations serving people at risk of opioid overdose, overdose education materials
community_programs.eligibility: Organizations and individuals at risk of opioid-related overdose; partners include first responders, treatment programs
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through participating pharmacies and partner organizations

community_programs.name: Let's Be Clear SD
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution resources and pharmacy participation coordination
community_programs.eligibility: General public
community_programs.in_person_locations: Participating pharmacies throughout South Dakota

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primary focus on people who use drugs and those closely connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Works through partnerships with local harm reduction organizations. Serves all 50 states including South Dakota as part of Midwest regional network.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Walk into any South Dakota pharmacy and ask for naloxone under the statewide standing order. No prescription needed. OTC Narcan nasal spray is also available at pharmacies and online retailers. South Dakota Department of Health distributes free naloxone to organizations serving at-risk populations.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas may have limited pharmacy access. NEXT Distro provides free mail-based naloxone delivery statewide for those without local resources. Use GoodRx coupon to reduce pharmacy costs. Contact local health departments for free community program access.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: No specific language accessibility information documented. Contact South Dakota Department of Health for accommodation details.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is fully legal to possess, distribute, and administer in Tennessee. Pharmacists can dispense without individual prescription under standing order. Covered by insurance including TennCare (Medicaid).

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Tennessee allows pharmacists to dispense naloxone on a statewide standing order basis. Law allows pharmacists to dispense to anyone at risk of opioid overdose or to family members, friends, or close associates without a prescription. Tennessee Department of Health provides training and education resources.

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Civil immunity for prescribers dispensing naloxone and civil immunity for laypersons administering naloxone in good faith to someone reasonably believed to be experiencing opioid overdose. Public Chapter 623 provides comprehensive protections.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Training requirement: persons administering naloxone must receive basic instruction including quiz and certificate printing. Protections apply when person reasonably believes someone is overdosing on opioid.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists with training from Tennessee Department of Health can dispense naloxone under standing order to anyone at risk of opioid overdose or to third parties (family, friends, associates) without prescription.
pharmacies.typical_cost: Covered by insurance including TennCare. OTC Narcan typically $44-50 with GoodRx coupon when paying out-of-pocket. No copay typically required for Medicaid beneficiaries.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: TennCare (Tennessee Medicaid) fully covers naloxone. Covered as both branded Narcan nasal spray and generic formulations. No authorization typically required.

community_programs.name: Tennessee Save a Life Program
community_programs.type: state overdose education and naloxone distribution program
community_programs.services: Naloxone training and distribution to treatment facilities, recovery support services, recovery courts, and high-risk populations. Fentanyl test strips distribution.
community_programs.eligibility: Individuals and organizations at risk of opioid-related overdose; treatment facilities; recovery programs
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through health departments, treatment facilities, and community organizations; over 35,000 Tennesseans trained annually

community_programs.name: Tennessee Harm Reduction Programs (Licensed Syringe Service Programs)
community_programs.services: Naloxone provision, syringe exchange, fentanyl test strips, HIV/HCV testing, linkage to treatment and recovery resources
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and at-risk populations; confidential and low-barrier
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple licensed syringe service programs throughout Tennessee; searchable map available on Tennessee Department of Health website

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order harm reduction program with regional partnerships
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected to them; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Works through regional partnerships. Tennessee is part of the South/Central regional network served by NEXT Distro.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Tennessee pharmacy and ask for naloxone under the standing order; no prescription needed. TennCare covers the cost. Call Tennessee Department of Health for information about free naloxone from community programs and syringe service programs. OTC Narcan is available at pharmacies and online retailers.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Some rural areas have limited pharmacy access; use NEXT Distro for free mail delivery. Stigma may exist at some pharmacies; assertively request under standing order or contact state health department for alternative resources. TennCare coverage eliminates cost barriers for eligible individuals.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: No specific multilingual naloxone resources documented. Contact Tennessee Department of Health and specific community programs for language accessibility accommodations.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Texas Health & Safety Code allows accredited pharmacists to dispense naloxone without a prescription through standing orders. OTC Narcan available at pharmacies and online.

standing_order_or_protocol.type: statewide standing order and pharmacy standing orders
standing_order_or_protocol.description: Any pharmacy or organization in Texas can request a free standing order to distribute naloxone. Pharmacists and employees/volunteers of organizations can dispense naloxone without prescription under the standing order. Authorized dispensers are legally protected.
key_statutes_or_policies: Texas Opioid Training Initiative standing order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Limited protection: Texas law provides immunity for persons administering naloxone in good faith and with reasonable care (Section 483.106). Does not cover basic drug possession protections like some other states.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Protects against criminal prosecution, professional licensing sanctions, or civil liability for administration/non-administration of naloxone if done in good faith with reasonable care. Does not provide immunity from drug possession charges for calling 911 in overdose situations.

pharmacies.mechanism: Texas pharmacists operating under standing orders (available free through TXOTI and other providers) can dispense naloxone directly to anyone requesting it without a prescription. OTC Narcan also available at major pharmacies.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan at retail ~$100-120 per formulation; approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon or comparison shopping. Participating pharmacies may offer free or reduced-cost naloxone under standing order programs.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Texas Medicaid (CHIP) covers naloxone. Coverage varies by individual plan; recommend contacting your insurance or pharmacy for specific copay information.

community_programs.name: Texas Opioid Training Initiative (TXOTI)
community_programs.type: state opioid response training and standing order provider
community_programs.services: Free naloxone standing orders for pharmacies and organizations; training resources; distribution support
community_programs.eligibility: Any pharmacy or organization in Texas can request a free standing order
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide; standing order enables naloxone access at participating pharmacies throughout Texas

community_programs.name: Texas Targeted Opioid Response (TTOR) Program
community_programs.type: state harm reduction and opioid response initiative
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, fentanyl test strips, training for healthcare professionals and community members; harm reduction support
community_programs.eligibility: General public and organizations at risk of opioid-related overdose
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple locations statewide through health departments and community partners

community_programs.name: Harm Reduction Organizations (volunteer-run)
community_programs.type: community harm reduction organizations in urban centers
community_programs.services: Naloxone provision, wound care, first aid, sterile supplies, menstrual supplies, hygiene kits, HIV/HCV testing, safer use support
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs; free and confidential
community_programs.in_person_locations: El Paso, Fort Worth, Abilene, Waco (volunteer-run organizations serving specific regions)

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order harm reduction program with regional partnerships
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Texas is part of the South/Central regional network. NEXT partners with local organizations to coordinate mail delivery.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Texas pharmacy and ask for OTC Narcan or request naloxone under standing order (no prescription needed). Contact Texas Opioid Training Initiative for free standing orders if pharmacy doesn't have one. Use NEXT Distro for free mail-based naloxone. Local syringe service programs and harm reduction organizations distribute naloxone free.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas may have limited pharmacy coverage; use NEXT Distro or contact TTOR for regional resources. Cost can be barrier; use GoodRx coupon, ask pharmacy about standing order program discounts, or access free community programs. Limited good samaritan protections for drug possession.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Texas Targeted Opioid Response program provides materials and training; specific language accessibility features should be confirmed by contacting TTOR directly.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Utah has a statewide standing order allowing pharmacists to dispense naloxone without a prescription to anyone at increased risk of opioid overdose.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Utah Department of Health issued a statewide standing order allowing pharmacists to dispense naloxone without a prior prescription to anyone at increased risk of experiencing an opioid overdose. Pharmacies may voluntarily register with UDOH. Pharmacists must report annually on naloxone units dispensed and products used.
key_statutes_or_policies: Utah Department of Health statewide standing order (2016)

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: HB 11 (2014) provides immunity from prosecution for possession of controlled substance or illicit drugs when reporting overdose. Requires reporting to 911, staying with overdose victim until medical aid arrives, and cooperating with authorities.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Protects individuals who report overdoses and those experiencing overdose. Law recognizes that no person should die from overdose due to fear of criminal charges. Some law enforcement lack awareness; document officer information in case of confusion about immunity.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists at registered pharmacies dispense naloxone under the statewide standing order to anyone at risk of opioid overdose. No prescription required. OTC Narcan also available. Extensive pharmacy network participates.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan costs approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Many participating pharmacies offer standing order naloxone at reduced cost or free.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Utah Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage varies by plan; Medicaid beneficiaries should have minimal or no copay for naloxone.

community_programs.name: Utah Department of Health and Human Services - Stop the Opidemic
community_programs.type: state opioid prevention and harm reduction initiative
community_programs.services: Naloxone training and ordering, fentanyl test strip locator, overdose prevention education, clinical resources
community_programs.eligibility: General public and healthcare providers
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through local health departments and community organizations; online ordering available

community_programs.name: Local Health Department Syringe Service Programs
community_programs.services: Syringe exchange, naloxone distribution and training, overdose prevention education, linkage to treatment services
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and at-risk individuals; low-barrier access
community_programs.in_person_locations: Served through 13 local health departments across Utah; varies by region

community_programs.name: Utah Naloxone Standing Order Pharmacy Network
community_programs.services: Naloxone rescue kits (OTC and prescription), pharmacy training and coordination
community_programs.eligibility: General public
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide pharmacy network including major chains and independent pharmacies; map available online

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Utah is part of the Western regional network. NEXT Distro partnerships with local organizations enable statewide mail delivery.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Utah pharmacy on the standing order network and request naloxone without prescription. Use online pharmacy locator map at Utah Naloxone Standing Order website. OTC Narcan available at major pharmacies. Contact Stop the Opidemic program for training and ordering. Local health departments offer free naloxone through syringe service programs.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas may have limited pharmacy access; use NEXT Distro for mail delivery or contact local health department. Cost is reduced for Medicaid beneficiaries. Some awareness gaps about HB 11 good samaritan protections; document law enforcement officer information if issues arise.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Stop the Opidemic website and materials available; specific language accessibility should be confirmed by contacting Utah Department of Health and Human Services directly.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is fully legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Vermont has robust standing order authorization for naloxone distribution through pharmacies and community organizations.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Vermont standing order issued under 18 V.S.A. § 4257(c)(1) allows pharmacists to dispense naloxone and devices to eligible persons (at risk of overdose or in position to assist) without a prescription. Standing order remains in effect until August 31, 2027. Authorized for both intranasal and auto-injector forms.
key_statutes_or_policies: Vermont Department of Health standing order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: 18 VSA § 4254 provides strong protections: immunity from prosecution for seeking or providing medical assistance for drug overdose; protects possession of controlled substances and paraphernalia; applies to both overdose victims and those seeking help.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Extensive protections including immunity from forfeiture laws (except prima facie contraband). Good faith effort to seek emergency assistance counts as mitigating factor at sentencing. Law enforcement immune from liability for arrests later determined to qualify for immunity.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists can dispense naloxone under statewide standing order to any person without a prescription. OTC Narcan also available at pharmacies. Standing order covers both nasal spray and auto-injector forms.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Pharmacies may offer standing order dispensing at reduced cost or free.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Vermont Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage applies to both branded Narcan and generic formulations. Minimal copay barriers for eligible beneficiaries.

community_programs.name: Vermont Department of Health - Opioid Overdose Prevention and Reversal Project (OOPRP)
community_programs.services: Naloxone rescue kit distribution, overdose response training, opioid misuse prevention training, EMS leave-behind naloxone program, treatment referrals
community_programs.eligibility: General public; EMS leave-behind program targets patients at risk
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through community-based organizations, health departments, and EMS providers; program map available online

community_programs.name: Community-Based Organizations and Health Departments
community_programs.type: local harm reduction and community health organizations
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, overdose prevention training, syringe exchange, referrals to treatment and recovery services
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs and at-risk populations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple locations statewide through Vermont Department of Health partnerships

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Vermont statewide coverage. NEXT Distro partners with local organizations for mail delivery and follow-up support.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Vermont pharmacy and request naloxone under standing order (no prescription needed). OTC Narcan available at major pharmacies. Contact Vermont Department of Health for information about OOPRP program, EMS leave-behind naloxone, and community organization access. Use NEXT Distro for free mail-delivered naloxone.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural/remote areas may have limited pharmacy access; use NEXT Distro mail service. Vermont's strong good samaritan law eliminates legal barriers to calling 911 during overdoses. EMS leave-behind program ensures patients discharged after nonfatal overdose receive naloxone.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Vermont Department of Health website includes multilingual resources for opioid prevention. Specific language accessibility of naloxone training materials should be confirmed directly with Department of Health.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Virginia has statewide standing order and community organization dispensing authorization. OTC Narcan available at pharmacies.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Virginia Department of Health issued statewide standing order effective February 10, 2023, authorizing licensed pharmacies, pharmacists, and community organizations to dispense naloxone to anyone. Standing order allows both individual possession and organizational distribution. Board of Pharmacy and Board of Medicine develop dispensing protocols.
key_statutes_or_policies: Virginia Department of Health statewide standing order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: New law HB 2117 effective July 1, 2025 expands protections: immunity from arrest/prosecution for unlawful purchase, possession, or consumption of controlled substance (when seeking emergency help for overdose). Applies to those calling 911 and to overdose victims themselves.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Requires identification and cooperation with responding officers; immunity only applies to evidence from the decision to seek help. Additional protections: cannot be sent back to jail on parole/probation violations for covered drug offenses. Previous law (18.2-251.03) already provided some protections.

pharmacies.mechanism: Virginia pharmacists dispense naloxone under statewide standing order without individual prescription. Community organizations can also dispense under standing order. OTC Narcan available at major pharmacies.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Standing order dispensing may be available at reduced cost through pharmacies.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Virginia Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage includes both branded Narcan and generic formulations. Beneficiaries should have minimal copay.

community_programs.name: Virginia Department of Health - Naloxone Distribution
community_programs.type: state health department naloxone dispensing authorization
community_programs.services: Standing order authorization for pharmacies and community organizations to dispense naloxone
community_programs.eligibility: General public; community service boards offer no-cost naloxone to eligible individuals
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide through licensed pharmacies and authorized community organizations

community_programs.name: Virginia Harm Reduction Coalition
community_programs.services: Naloxone provision, syringe exchange, overdose prevention education, safer use supplies, wound care, HIV/HCV testing
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs; free and confidential
community_programs.in_person_locations: Roanoke area and Central Virginia; provides outreach and mobile services

community_programs.name: Virginia Naloxone Project
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution through hospitals with grant funding support
community_programs.eligibility: Individuals seeking emergency care; hospital-based access
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple hospital locations across Virginia with expansion ongoing

community_programs.name: LENOWISCO/Cumberland Plateau Harm Reduction Program
community_programs.type: community harm reduction and syringe service program
community_programs.services: Naloxone provision and training, syringe exchange, wound care, safer supplies, testing, treatment referrals
community_programs.eligibility: Injection drug users and at-risk individuals; confidential
community_programs.in_person_locations: Wise County Health Department, Tazewell County Health Department, mobile locations in western Virginia

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order harm reduction program with regional partnerships
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Virginia is served through South/Central regional network of NEXT Distro.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Virginia pharmacy and request naloxone under statewide standing order (no prescription needed). OTC Narcan available at major retailers. Contact Virginia Department of Health for community organization locations. Virginia Harm Reduction Coalition serves Roanoke area. Use NEXT Distro for free mail-based access.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas in southwest Virginia (Wise, Tazewell counties) have dedicated harm reduction programs. Community service boards offer no-cost naloxone for eligible individuals. New HB 2117 law eliminates legal barriers to calling 911 for overdose assistance. Cost-free mail service via NEXT Distro.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Virginia Department of Health provides resources. Specific language accessibility should be confirmed with VDH or participating community organizations.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Washington has a collaborative statewide standing order allowing pharmacists and non-medical personnel to dispense naloxone without prescription.

standing_order_or_protocol.type: statewide standing order collaborative drug therapy agreement
standing_order_or_protocol.description: Washington State Health Officer issued statewide standing order effective August 28, 2019. Allows pharmacists and non-medical personnel to dispense naloxone to any person at risk of experiencing opioid-related overdose or in a position to assist. Stands alone like a prescription; pharmacists fill in recipient information. Available in both nasal spray and injectable forms.
key_statutes_or_policies: Washington State Department of Health standing order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: RCW 69.50.315 provides immunity from prosecution for drug possession charges when seeking medical assistance in drug-related overdose. Protects both the person seeking help and the overdose victim. RCW 4.24.300 provides general civil immunity for emergency assistance.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Person seeking help cannot be prosecuted for drug possession based on evidence obtained from overdose response. Overdose victim also protected from drug possession charges. Anyone in WA is allowed to carry and administer naloxone.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists dispense naloxone under statewide standing order to eligible persons without prescription. Individuals may bring printed or digital copy of standing order to pharmacy. OTC Narcan also available at major pharmacies and online.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Standing order dispensing available at reduced cost or free depending on pharmacy.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Washington Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage includes both branded Narcan and generic formulations. Minimal copay for eligible beneficiaries.

mail_based_programs.notes: Washington is served through Western regional network of NEXT Distro. State also offers online ordering and free mail delivery of naloxone.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Washington pharmacy and request naloxone under standing order (no prescription needed); bring digital/printed copy of standing order if available. OTC Narcan available at pharmacies and online. Use Washington State website for standing order copy. Contact health districts for community programs. Order free naloxone online from state program.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Rural areas served through standing order at regional pharmacies. No identification or proof of need required for standing order access. State offers free online ordering. Strong good samaritan law removes fear of prosecution for seeking overdose assistance. Reasonable identification only requirement.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Washington Department of Health website provides resources; specific language accessibility should be confirmed with DOH directly.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. West Virginia has statewide standing order allowing pharmacists to dispense naloxone without prescription. State also authorizes harm reduction and syringe service programs.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: West Virginia State Health Officer issued statewide standing order allowing pharmacists to dispense naloxone to persons at risk of opioid-related overdose or family members, friends, and others in a position to assist, without prescription. West Virginia Board of Pharmacy requires dispensing be accompanied by counseling on overdose signs, airway management, treatment information, proper use, and notification of Good Samaritan law.
key_statutes_or_policies: West Virginia State Health Officer standing order
West Virginia Board of Pharmacy guidelines

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: West Virginia Code Article 47 provides immunity: person seeking medical assistance for overdose cannot be cited, arrested, or prosecuted for drug possession violations when evidence stems from overdose response. Article 47 Section 4 provides limited immunity from prosecution.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: State has specific treatment requirements in some cases for immunity eligibility. West Virginia has the highest overdose mortality rate in the nation; strong protections intended to encourage treatment-seeking behavior.

pharmacies.mechanism: Pharmacists operating under statewide standing order dispense naloxone without prescription to anyone at risk or in position to assist. Research shows limited implementation despite standing order; persistent barriers include inconsistent pharmacy stocking and pharmacist knowledge. Board of Pharmacy requires training and reporting.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Standing order dispensing varies by pharmacy; some offer free or reduced-cost naloxone.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: West Virginia Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage applies to both branded Narcan and generic formulations. Medicaid beneficiaries typically face minimal or no copay.

community_programs.services: Naloxone and naloxone training, sterile syringes, recovery coaching, HIV/HBV/HCV testing and vaccinations, wound care, linkage to treatment and social services
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs; low-barrier access
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple certified programs statewide at county health departments and nonprofit organizations including Cabell-Huntington Health Department, Marion County Health Department, Ohio County Health Department, and others

community_programs.name: Women's Health Center of West Virginia - Harm Reduction Program
community_programs.services: Free and confidential naloxone, safe-use supplies, overdose prevention training, health screening, linkage to care
community_programs.eligibility: All genders; people who use drugs
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide program

community_programs.name: West Virginia Harm Reduction Coalition
community_programs.services: Coordination of harm reduction services, advocacy for expanded access and reduced stigma
community_programs.eligibility: Support for harm reduction efforts statewide
community_programs.in_person_locations: Operates across West Virginia; founded 2017

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order harm reduction program with regional partnership
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: West Virginia is served through South/Central regional network with direct partnership linkages documented.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Contact West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources for certified harm reduction program locations. Many county health departments operate programs offering free naloxone. Visit pharmacies offering standing order naloxone. OTC Narcan available at pharmacies. Use NEXT Distro for free mail delivery. Women's Health Center offers statewide access.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Implementation barriers exist despite standing order—some pharmacies unaware or under-stock naloxone. Research shows limited accessibility for people who use drugs at some pharmacies. Harm reduction programs offer reliable free access. NEXT Distro and county health departments are workarounds for pharmacy barriers. Medicaid beneficiaries have coverage.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: West Virginia harm reduction programs provide services; specific language accessibility should be confirmed with individual programs or state health department.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Wisconsin established statewide standing orders for naloxone dispensing through pharmacists and nurses.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Wisconsin Department of Health Services issued statewide naloxone standing order authorizing participating pharmacists to dispense naloxone to individuals at risk of opioid-related overdose or individuals in a position to assist. Standing order is centralized and predetermined, allowing pharmacists to dispense without patient-specific prescription. Unlimited refills authorized.
key_statutes_or_policies: Wisconsin Department of Health Services standing order

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Wisconsin Statute § 450.11 provides immunity: any person acting in good faith in emergency situation is immune from civil liability. Additional specific rules allow immunity for delivering/dispensing opioid antagonist and administering it when reasonably believing someone is experiencing overdose.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Broad Good Samaritan protections for emergency care. Specific opioid overdose protections allow summoning emergency help without drug prosecution fear. Law covers civil and criminal liability for good faith naloxone delivery and administration.

pharmacies.mechanism: Participating Wisconsin pharmacists dispense naloxone under statewide standing order to eligible persons without prescription. Pharmacy must register and maintain standing order on file. OTC Narcan also available at pharmacies.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Standing order dispensing may be available at reduced cost or free through participating pharmacies.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Wisconsin Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage applies to both branded Narcan and generic formulations. Medicaid beneficiaries have minimal or no copay.

community_programs.in_person_locations: Montello, Wisconsin

community_programs.name: Wisconsin Harm Reduction Initiatives
community_programs.services: Naloxone distribution, syringe services, overdose prevention education, recovery support
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs; low-barrier
community_programs.in_person_locations: Multiple locations statewide through community organizations

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.provider_type: national mail-order harm reduction program with regional partnership
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Wisconsin is served through Midwest regional network of NEXT Distro.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Contact Wisconsin Department of Health Services for list of enrolled pharmacies dispensing under standing order. Visit participating pharmacy and request naloxone without prescription. OTC Narcan available at major pharmacies. Contact community harm reduction programs for free naloxone. Use NEXT Distro for free mail-based delivery.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Not all Wisconsin pharmacies participate in standing order program; use DHS website to find enrolled pharmacies. Rural areas may have limited pharmacy participation. Community harm reduction programs and NEXT Distro provide alternatives. Medicaid coverage eliminates cost barriers for eligible individuals.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Wisconsin Department of Health Services provides standing order resources; specific language accessibility should be confirmed directly with DHS.

legal_framework.naloxone_legal_status: Naloxone is legal to possess, distribute, and administer. Wyoming law allows pharmacists and practitioners to prescribe naloxone directly to persons at risk of overdose. No statewide standing order exists, but OTC Narcan available.

standing_order_or_protocol.description: Wyoming does not have a statewide standing order. Instead, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 35-4-901 et seq. allows practitioners and pharmacists to directly prescribe naloxone to persons at risk of experiencing overdose or in a position to assist. Practitioners may issue standing orders to entities establishing drug overdose treatment programs. Department of Health recommends entities obtain standing order from licensed provider.
key_statutes_or_policies: Wyoming Department of Health guidelines on naloxone prescribing

good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.scope: Senate File 74, signed into law March 2025, provides immunity for overdose reporting. Person can make emergency call for overdose assistance and receive protection from misdemeanor possession/use charges if they remain on scene and are honest with first responders. Wyoming was the last state to enact overdose immunity law.
good_samaritan_overdose_immunity.notes: Provides immunity up to two times per calendar year (compromise between Senate and House versions). Does not grant immunity for felonies like intent to deliver. Wyoming previously had no good samaritan law; SF 74 fills major gap in overdose assistance protections.

pharmacies.mechanism: Wyoming pharmacists and practitioners can directly prescribe naloxone without a statewide standing order. Individuals can request naloxone at local pharmacies; pharmacists have authority to provide it. OTC Narcan available at major pharmacies and online retailers.
pharmacies.typical_cost: OTC Narcan approximately $44-50 with GoodRx coupon; retail approximately $100-120. Pharmacy-dispensed naloxone under practitioner prescribing authority varies in cost.
pharmacies.medicaid_coverage_notes: Wyoming Medicaid covers naloxone. Coverage applies to both branded Narcan and generic formulations. Medicaid beneficiaries should have minimal copay.

community_programs.services: Naloxone prescribing assistance, overdose prevention information, harm reduction resources
community_programs.eligibility: General public and organizations
community_programs.in_person_locations: Statewide coordination through health department

community_programs.name: Wyoming Harm Reduction Organizations
community_programs.services: Naloxone provision, syringe exchange, peer recovery coaching, overdose prevention education
community_programs.eligibility: People who use drugs; low-barrier
community_programs.in_person_locations: Limited number of programs; primarily in urban areas

mail_based_programs.name: NEXT Distro
mail_based_programs.eligibility: Primarily for people who use drugs and those directly connected; mail-based access for those without community resources
mail_based_programs.notes: Wyoming is served through Western regional network of NEXT Distro.

practical_guidance.how_to_get_naloxone_quickly: Visit any Wyoming pharmacy and ask for naloxone; pharmacists have prescribing authority. OTC Narcan available at major pharmacies and online. Contact Wyoming Department of Health for assistance obtaining naloxone or connecting with organizations; email provided for standing order help. Use NEXT Distro for free mail-delivered naloxone.
practical_guidance.barriers_and_workarounds: Wyoming has limited harm reduction infrastructure compared to other states. New good samaritan law (SF 74, effective 2025) removes major legal barrier to calling 911 for overdose. Rural access limited; use NEXT Distro for mail service. Department of Health can assist in obtaining standing order for entities.
practical_guidance.languages_and_accessibility: Wyoming Department of Health provides overdose response resources; specific language accessibility should be confirmed by contacting department directly.
